qas.question: Who could wear a emblem of two crossed silver oak leaves?

answers.text: Any individual made a member of the Order for gallantry
two crossed silver oak leaves on the same riband, ribbon or bow as the badge

qas.question: What kind of medal was replaced in 1974?
They continued to wear what the insignia of what?

answers.text: lower grade with the oak leaves

context: <a0_0>Any individual made a member of the Order for gallantry<a0_0/> could wear an emblem of <a1_0>two crossed silver oak leaves on the same riband, ribbon or bow as the badge<a1_0/>. It could not be awarded posthumously and was effectively replaced in <a2_0>1974<a2_0/> with the <a3_0>Queen's Gallantry Medal<a3_0/>. If recipients of the Order of the British Empire for Gallantry received promotion within the Order, whether for gallantry or otherwise, they continued to wear also the insignia of the <a4_0>lower grade with the oak leaves<a4_0/>. However, they only used the post-nominal letters of the higher grade.
